title: ```qmd
text:
Introduction







In many applications, data is spread across multiple files or databases.
It may also be arranged in a format not suitable for easy analysis.
This chapter focuses on tools to combine, join, and rearrange data effectively.
Key concept: Hierarchical Indexing in pandas.

title: ```qmd
section: Data Wrangling, Data Mining, Machine Learning
text:
Data Wrangling, Data Mining, Machine Learning






What is Data Wrangling?



Data Wrangling (or Data Munging) is the process of transforming and mapping data from one ‚Äúraw‚Äù data form into another format with the intent of making it more appropriate and valuable for a variety of downstream purposes such as analytics.





What is Data Mining?



Data mining is the process of discovering patterns, anomalies, and correlations within large datasets to predict outcomes.




What is Machine Learning?

Machine Learning is a subfield of artificial intelligence.
It focuses on developing systems that can learn from and make decisions/predictions based on data.
Supervised Learning: Uses labeled datasets to train algorithms.
Unsupervised Learning: Discovers hidden patterns in unlabeled data.
Reinforcement Learning: Agents learn by interacting with an environment.

Hierarchical Indexing in Pandas

A fundamental feature of pandas.
Enables having multiple (two or more) index levels on an axis.
Allows working with higher dimensional data in a lower dimensional form.



Analogy: Think of it like having subcategories within categories in a file cabinet.
Benefit: Provides a structured way to represent and manipulate complex datasets.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

data = pd.Series(np.random.uniform(size=9),
                 index=[["a", "a", "a", "b", "b", "c", "c", "d", "d"],
                        [1, 2, 3, 1, 3, 1, 2, 2, 3]])

We create a Series with a list of lists as the index.
This creates a MultiIndex object.
The ‚Äúgaps‚Äù in the index display indicate ‚Äúuse the label directly above‚Äù.

Combining and Merging Datasets
Three main ways to combine data in pandas:







pandas.merge: Connects rows in DataFrames based on one or more keys (like SQL joins).
pandas.concat: Concatenates or ‚Äústacks‚Äù objects together along an axis.
combine_first: Splices together overlapping data (fills missing values).

title: ```qmd
text:
pandas.merge Function Arguments







Argument
Description




left
DataFrame to be merged on the left side.


right
DataFrame to be merged on the right side.


how
Type of join: ‚Äúinner‚Äù, ‚Äúouter‚Äù, ‚Äúleft‚Äù, or ‚Äúright‚Äù (defaults to ‚Äúinner‚Äù).


on
Column names to join on (must be in both DataFrames).


left_on
Columns in left DataFrame to use as join keys.


right_on
Analogous to left_on for the right DataFrame.


left_index
Use row index in left as its join key(s).


right_index
Analogous to left_index.


sort
Sort merged data lexicographically by join keys (False by default).


suffixes
Tuple of strings to append to overlapping column names (defaults to (‚Äú_x‚Äù, ‚Äú_y‚Äù)).


copy
If False, avoid copying data in some cases (defaults to copying).


validate
Verifies if the merge is of specified type (one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many).


indicator
Adds a special column _merge that indicates the source of each row (‚Äúleft_only‚Äù, ‚Äúright_only‚Äù, or ‚Äúboth‚Äù).

title: More on the IPython System
text:
In previous chapters, we touched upon the basics of the IPython shell and Jupyter notebooks.
Now, we‚Äôll dive deeper into IPython‚Äôs functionalities, useful both in console and Jupyter.
Think of IPython as your enhanced Python interpreter, a powerful tool for interactive computing and data analysis.
This appendix supplements your learning material, like a power-up in a video game! üéÆ

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Terminal Keyboard Shortcuts ‚å®Ô∏è

IPython boasts numerous keyboard shortcuts for efficient navigation and command history interaction.
Familiar to users of Emacs or Unix bash shell.
Mastering these shortcuts will significantly boost your productivity! ‚ö°

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Terminal Keyboard Shortcuts (Continued)






The below table lists some of standard IPython keyboard shortcuts.










Keyboard Shortcut
Description




Ctrl-P or Up Arrow
Search backward in command history (matching current text)


Ctrl-N or Down Arrow
Search forward in command history (matching current text)


Ctrl-R
Readline-style reverse history search (partial matching)


Ctrl-Shift-V
Paste text from clipboard


Ctrl-C
Interrupt currently executing code üõë


Ctrl-A
Move cursor to beginning of line


Ctrl-E
Move cursor to end of line


Ctrl-K
Delete text from cursor to end of line


Ctrl-U
Discard all text on current line


Ctrl-F
Move cursor forward one character


Ctrl-B
Move cursor backward one character


Ctrl-L
Clear screen üí®

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Visualizing Shortcuts üñºÔ∏è






This figure illustrates some of the keyboard shortcuts in action within the IPython shell.





C-b, C-f: Move cursor back/forward (like Ctrl-B, Ctrl-F).
C-a, C-e: Jump to start/end of line (like Ctrl-A, Ctrl-E).
C-k: Delete text to end of line (like Ctrl-K).
C-u: Delete entire line (like Ctrl-U).
The shortcuts marked on the a_variable are operations on the text.







Jupyter notebooks have their own set of shortcuts. Explore Jupyter‚Äôs integrated help!

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Magic Commands: IPython‚Äôs Superpowers üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Magic commands are special commands unique to IPython, not built-in Python.
Prefixed with the percent symbol (%).
They streamline common tasks and allow you to control IPython‚Äôs behavior. Think of them as ‚Äúshortcuts‚Äù for IPython itself!

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Example: %timeit ‚è±Ô∏è

%timeit measures the execution time of a Python statement. Very useful for performance analysis!

import numpy as np
a = np.random.standard_normal((100, 100))
%timeit np.dot(a, a)

The output shows the average execution time and standard deviation over multiple runs.
In the result 92.5 ¬µs ¬± 3.43 ¬µs per loop (mean ¬± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10000 loops each), ¬µs means microsecond.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Exploring Magic Commands ‚ùì

Use ? after a magic command to view its ‚Äúcommand-line‚Äù options (like a help manual).

%debug?






This will show the detailed usage of the %debug command, including how to activate the interactive debugger, set breakpoints, and use it in post-mortem mode.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
automagic: Magic Without the % ‚ú®

automagic lets you use magic commands without the % prefix, as long as no variable has the same name.
Toggle it on/off with %automagic.

%automagic  # Turns automagic on or off
pwd         # Equivalent to %pwd (if automagic is on and 'pwd' isn't a variable)

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Assigning Magic Command Output

Some magic commands behave like functions; you can assign their output to variables.

directory = %pwd  # Stores the current working directory in 'directory'
print(directory)

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Essential Magic Commands üìú






Here are some frequently used IPython magic commands:










Command
Description




%quickref
Display the IPython Quick Reference Card


%magic
Display detailed documentation for all available magic commands


%debug
Enter the interactive debugger at the last exception traceback


%hist
Print command input history (with optional output)


%pdb
Automatically enter debugger after any exception


%paste
Execute preformatted Python code from clipboard


%cpaste
Open a special prompt for manually pasting code


%reset
Delete all variables/names in the interactive namespace


%page OBJECT
Pretty-print an object and display it through a pager


%run script.py
Run a Python script inside IPython


%prun statement
Execute a statement with cProfile and report profiler output


%time statement
Report the execution time of a single statement.


%timeit statement
Run a statement multiple times to compute an average execution time; useful for timing code with very short execution time.


%who, %who_ls, %whos
Display variables defined in interactive namespace, with varying levels of information/verbosity.


%xdel variable
Delete a variable and attempt to clear any references to the object in the IPython internals.




Press q to exit the %quickref or %magic pager.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
The %run Command üèÉ

Executes a Python script within your IPython session.
The script runs in an empty namespace (no prior imports or variables).
Variables, functions, and imports from the script become accessible in your IPython shell after execution.

# In a file named 'my_script.py':
def my_function(x):
    return x * 2

result = my_function(5)

# In IPython:
%run my_script.py
print(result)  # Output: 10

title: More on the IPython System
text:
%run -i: Accessing Existing Variables

%run -i lets the script access variables already defined in your IPython session.

# In IPython:
my_var = 10

# In 'script_with_access.py':
print(my_var * 3)

# Back in IPython:
%run -i script_with_access.py  # Output: 30

title: More on the IPython System
text:
%load: Importing Scripts into Cells (Jupyter)

In Jupyter notebooks, %load imports a script directly into a code cell.

# %load my_script.py  # This will be replaced by the script's content

Then, the code cell content will be:

def my_function(x):
    return x * 2

result = my_function(5)

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Interrupting Running Code ‚úã

Press Ctrl-C to interrupt running code (whether from %run or a long command).
Raises a KeyboardInterrupt, stopping most Python programs immediately.
Sometimes, with compiled extensions, Ctrl-C might not work instantly.







If Ctrl-C doesn‚Äôt immediately stop execution (especially when compiled extensions are involved), you may need to forcibly terminate the Python process using your operating system‚Äôs tools (e.g., Task Manager on Windows, kill on Linux).

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Executing Code from the Clipboard üìã

%paste and %cpaste are handy for running code copied from elsewhere (but not needed in Jupyter, where direct pasting works).
%paste executes the clipboard content as a single block.
%cpaste opens a special prompt, letting you paste multiple blocks and edit before execution. Press Ctrl-D in the prompt to execute, and press Ctrl-C to exit the prompt.

# Example code on clipboard:
x = 5
if x > 2:
    print("x is greater than 2")

# In IPython:
%paste  # Executes the code immediately

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Command History: Your IPython Memory üß†

IPython keeps a small database of your executed commands. This is incredibly useful for:

Searching and reusing past commands.
Persisting history between sessions.
Logging input/output to a file.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Searching and Reusing Commands üîé

Up Arrow (Ctrl-P): Search backward in history, matching typed text.
Down Arrow (Ctrl-N): Search forward in history.
Ctrl-R: Reverse-i-search (like in bash). Type characters, and it finds matching commands. Press Ctrl-R multiple times to cycle.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Input and Output Variables ‚Ü©Ô∏éÔ∏è

IPython stores input and output:

_ (one underscore): Previous output.
__ (two underscores): Second-to-last output.
_iX: Input of line X (e.g., _i5 for input on line 5) - stored as a string.
_X: Output of line X.


2 + 2      # Output: 4
result = _  # result is now 4
print(_i1)  # Prints the string "2 + 2"

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Working with History: %hist, %reset, %xdel

%hist: Prints input history (with or without line numbers).
%reset: Clears the interactive namespace (and optionally input/output caches).
%xdel variable: Removes a variable and tries to clear IPython‚Äôs internal references. Useful for memory management with large datasets.







IPython‚Äôs input/output history can keep large objects in memory even after you del them. Use %xdel and %reset carefully to avoid memory issues.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Interacting with the Operating System üíª

IPython lets you interact with your OS without leaving the shell.
Run shell commands, change directories, and capture command output.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Shell Commands with ! üí•

Start a line with ! to execute it as a shell command.

!ls  # Lists files in the current directory (Linux/macOS)
!dir # Lists files (Windows)

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Capturing Shell Output

Assign the output of a ! command to a variable.

file_list = !ls
print(file_list)  # Prints the list of files

The returned object is a custom list containing various versions of console output.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Python Variables in Shell Commands: $

Use $ to substitute Python variables into shell commands.

my_directory = "data_files"
!ls $my_directory  # Lists files in the 'data_files' directory

title: More on the IPython System
section: Aliases and Bookmarks: Shortcuts for Commands and Directories
text:
Aliases and Bookmarks: Shortcuts for Commands and Directories

%alias: Create shortcuts for shell commands.

%alias ll ls -l  # Creates an alias 'll' for 'ls -l'
ll /usr/bin  # Now you can use 'll'

%bookmark: Create bookmarks for frequently used directories.

%bookmark mydata /path/to/my/data
cd mydata       # Jumps to the bookmarked directory
%bookmark -l    # Lists all bookmarks

Aliases are not persistent between sessions (unless configured). Bookmarks are persistent.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Directory History

%cd: Change directory.
%pwd: return current directory.
%pushd: place current directory on stack and change to target directory.
%popd: Change to directory popped off the top of the stack.
%dirs: Return a list containing the current directory stack.
%dhist: Print the history of visited directories.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Environment Variable

%env: Return the system environment variables as a dictionary.
%matplotlib: Configure matplotlib integration options

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Software Development Tools üõ†Ô∏è

IPython isn‚Äôt just for interactive exploration; it‚Äôs also great for software development.
Key tools:

Interactive Debugger: Enhanced pdb.
Code Timing: %time and %timeit.
Profiling: %prun, %lprun.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Interactive Debugger: %debug üêû

%debug: Enters the debugger after an exception occurs (post-mortem debugging).
Drops you into the stack frame where the error happened.
Enhanced with tab completion, syntax highlighting, and traceback context.

# Suppose some_script.py has an error:
%run some_script.py
%debug  # Enters the debugger at the error point

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Debugger Commands üß≠

Inside the debugger:

u (up): Move up the call stack.
d (down): Move down the call stack.
s (step): Step into a function call.
n (next): Execute current line and move to the next line (at the current level).
c (continue): Continue execution until the next breakpoint or the end.
q (quit): Exit the debugger.
p variable: print value of variable
!variable : Examine variable contents, when the variable has the same name of a debugger command.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
%pdb: Automatic Debugging

%pdb: Automatically enters the debugger on any exception. Very useful for debugging!

%pdb on  # Turns on automatic debugging
# Now, any error will drop you into the debugger
%pdb off # Turns it off

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Using the Debugger for Development

%run -d script.py: Start the debugger before running the script. Type s to step into the script.
%run -d -b line_number script.py: Set a breakpoint at line_number.
set_trace(): A ‚Äúpoor man‚Äôs breakpoint‚Äù function you can insert into your code.
debug(function, *args, **kwargs) : Easily step into a specific function call.

title: More on the IPython System
More on the IPython System
text:
Code Timing: %time and %timeit (Again)

%time: Measures the execution time of a statement once.
%timeit: Measures execution time multiple times for a more accurate average. Best for very short operations.

my_list = list(range(100000))
%time for _ in range(100):  sum(my_list)
%timeit sum(my_list)

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Basic Profiling: %prun and %run -p üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Profiling tells you where your code spends its time.
%prun statement: Profiles a single Python statement.
%run -p script.py: Profiles an entire script.
Uses cProfile under the hood.
Output shows:

ncalls: Number of calls.
tottime: Total time spent in the function (excluding calls to sub-functions).
percall: Time per call (tottime / ncalls).
cumtime: Cumulative time spent in the function and its sub-functions.
percall: Cumulative time per call (cumtime / ncalls).
filename:lineno(function): Location of the function.


#Example
def slow_function():
    result = []
    for i in range(1000):
        result.append(i * 2)
    return result

%prun slow_function()

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Line Profiling: %lprun üìè

%lprun: Provides line-by-line profiling of specific functions. More detailed than %prun.
Requires the line_profiler IPython extension.

Enable: add c.InteractiveShellApp.extensions = ['line_profiler'] in ipython_config.py, or use %load_ext line_profiler.

Syntax: %lprun -f function1 -f function2 statement_to_profile
Output shows:

Line #: Line number.
Hits: Number of times the line was executed.
Time: Total time spent on the line (in timer units).
Per Hit: Time per execution of the line.
% Time: Percentage of total time spent on the line.
Line Contents: The actual code.


# Assuming line_profiler is enabled and prof_mod.py exists:
from prof_mod import add_and_sum, call_function #example file, you need create it.
%lprun -f add_and_sum call_function()

title: More on the IPython System
text:
Tips for Productive Code Development üìù

Reloading Module Dependencies:

Problem: Changes to imported modules aren‚Äôt automatically reflected in IPython.
Solutions:

importlib.reload(module): Reloads a single module.
dreload(module) (IPython-specific): Deep (recursive) reload of a module and its dependencies. More robust.


Code Design:

Keep relevant objects and data alive: Avoid putting all your code inside a main() function. Keep variables at the top level for easy inspection in IPython.
Flat is better than nested: Avoid deeply nested code. Makes debugging and testing easier.
Overcome a fear of longer files: Within reason, longer, well-organized modules are often better than many small, interconnected ones (reduces reloading overhead).
Maintain high internal cohesion: Related code should be grouped together.

title: More on the IPython System
text:
IPython Profiles and Configuration ‚öôÔ∏è

Customize IPython‚Äôs appearance and behavior through configuration files (ipython_config.py).
Located in your IPython directory (usually ~/.ipython/profile_default/).
You can have multiple profiles for different projects or settings.
Create a new profile: ipython profile create my_profile
Launch with a specific profile: ipython --profile=my_profile
Jupyter has its own configuration system.

IPython and Jupyter are powerful tools for both interactive exploration and software development.
Mastering their features ‚Äì shortcuts, magic commands, debugger, profiler, and configuration ‚Äì will significantly enhance your productivity.
Experiment and find a workflow that suits your style!

title: Plotting and Visualization
text:
Making informative visualizations (sometimes called plots) is one of the most important tasks in data analysis.


Exploratory Process: Helps identify outliers or needed data transformations.
Model Generation: Aids in generating ideas for models.
Web Visualization: Building interactive visualizations can be the end goal.







Note



Python has many add-on libraries for visualizations, but we‚Äôll focus on matplotlib and libraries built on top of it, such as seaborn.






A desktop plotting package for creating publication-quality plots and figures.
Started by John Hunter in 2002 to provide a MATLAB-like plotting interface in Python.

Why? ü§î To make it easier for scientists and engineers to create plots in Python, just like they did in MATLAB!

Collaborated with IPython to simplify interactive plotting.
Supports various GUI backends and export formats (PDF, SVG, JPG, PNG, BMP, GIF, etc.).
Most graphics in many books and publications are produced using matplotlib.







Tip



Matplotlib has spawned add-on toolkits like seaborn, enhancing its capabilities.





To display plots inline in Jupyter Notebook, use the magic command:
%matplotlib inline






Note



This command tells Jupyter to display matplotlib plots directly in the notebook output. Without it, you might not see your plots!






Many new visualization libraries have emerged since 2012.

Bokeh and Altair: Leverage modern web tech for interactive visualizations.

This course focuses on matplotlib due to its fundamental nature and integration with pandas.

Why matplotlib? ü§î It‚Äôs like learning to walk before you run! Understanding matplotlib helps you grasp the basics, making it easier to learn other libraries later.








Tip



Principles learned here are adaptable to other visualization libraries.





Import convention for matplotlib:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt






Note



This line imports the pyplot module from matplotlib and gives it a shorter name, plt. This is a common practice to make your code cleaner and easier to read.





import numpy as np
data = np.arange(10)
plt.plot(data)

np.arange(10): Creates an array of numbers from 0 to 9.
plt.plot(data): Plots the data as a line chart.










Figure 9-1. Simple line plot









Plots in matplotlib reside within a Figure object.

What‚Äôs a Figure? ü§î Think of it as a blank canvas where you can draw your plots.

Create a new figure using plt.figure():

fig = plt.figure()

plt.figure options:

figsize: Guarantees figure size and aspect ratio.






You can‚Äôt plot on a blank figure; create subplots using add_subplot:

ax1 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 1)

add_subplot(2, 2, 1) means:

A 2x2 grid of subplots (4 plots total).
Select the 1st subplot (numbered from 1).
Analogy: It is just like the form in Excel to select a range of cells.

Create additional subplots:

ax2 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 2)
ax3 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 3)









Figure 9-2. An empty matplotlib figure with three subplots














Note



In Jupyter Notebook, plots are reset after each cell. Put all plotting commands in a single cell.

Why? ü§î Jupyter runs each cell independently. If you split your plotting commands, you might only see the last plot!



fig = plt.figure()
ax1 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 1)
ax2 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 2)
ax3 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 3)




AxesSubplot objects have methods to create different plot types.
Preferred over top-level functions like plt.plot.
Example:

ax3.plot(np.random.standard_normal(50).cumsum(), color="black", linestyle="dashed")









Figure 9-3. Data visualization after a single plot









You might see output like <matplotlib.lines.Line2D at ...>.

What does this mean? ü§î It‚Äôs a reference to the plot element you just added. You can usually ignore it.

To suppress the output, add a semicolon (;) at the end of the line.

Why suppress? üßπ Keeps your notebook output clean and focused on the plots.


ax3.plot(np.random.standard_normal(50).cumsum(), color="black", linestyle="dashed"); # Note the semicolon



ax1.hist(np.random.standard_normal(100), bins=20, color="black", alpha=0.3)
ax2.scatter(np.arange(30), np.arange(30) + 3 * np.random.standard_normal(30))

ax1.hist(...): Creates a histogram.
ax2.scatter(...): Creates a scatter plot.
alpha=0.3: Sets the transparency of the plot.










Figure 9-4. Data visualization after additional plots









plt.subplots creates a figure and a NumPy array of subplot objects:

fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 3)
axes
array([[<AxesSubplot:>, <AxesSubplot:>, <AxesSubplot:>],
       [<AxesSubplot:>, <AxesSubplot:>, <AxesSubplot:>]], dtype=object)

Access subplots like a 2D array: axes[0, 1].
sharex and sharey: Share the same x or y-axis for comparing data.











Argument
Description




nrows
Number of rows of subplots


ncols
Number of columns of subplots


sharex
All subplots use the same x-axis ticks


sharey
All subplots use the same y-axis ticks


subplot_kw
Dictionary of keywords passed to add_subplot


**fig_kw
Additional keywords passed to subplots (e.g., figsize=(8, 6))









Table 9-1. matplotlib.pyplot.subplots options







Default padding and spacing between subplots.
Change spacing using the subplots_adjust method:

fig.subplots_adjust(left=None, bottom=None, right=None, top=None,
                    wspace=None, hspace=None)

wspace and hspace: Control the percentage of figure width/height for spacing.




fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2, sharex=True, sharey=True)
for i in range(2):
    for j in range(2):
        axes[i, j].hist(np.random.standard_normal(500), bins=50,
                        color="black", alpha=0.5)
fig.subplots_adjust(wspace=0, hspace=0)









Figure 9-5. Data visualization with no inter-subplot spacing









matplotlib doesn‚Äôt check for overlapping labels.
Fix labels by specifying tick locations and labels.
Covered in the ‚ÄúTicks, Labels, and Legends‚Äù section.





Customize line plots with color, markers, and line styles.
Example:

ax.plot(x, y, linestyle="--", color="green")

Use color names or hex codes (e.g., "#CECECE").
Line styles: Check plt.plot docstring (use plt.plot?).





Line plots can have markers to show actual data points.
Useful when interpolation might obscure point locations.
Example:

ax.plot(np.random.standard_normal(30).cumsum(), color="black",
        linestyle="dashed", marker="o")









Figure 9-6. Line plot with markers









Linear interpolation is the default.
Change with the drawstyle option:

ax.plot(data, color="black", linestyle="dashed", label="Default")
ax.plot(data, color="black", linestyle="dashed",
        drawstyle="steps-post", label="steps-post")
ax.legend()









Figure 9-7. Line plot with different drawstyle options









Plot decorations are accessed through matplotlib axes object methods.
xlim, xticks, xticklabels: Control plot range, tick locations, and labels.
Two ways to use:

No arguments: Returns the current value (e.g., ax.xlim()).
With parameters: Sets the value (e.g., ax.xlim([0, 10])).






Example: Random walk plot.

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(np.random.standard_normal(1000).cumsum())









Figure 9-8. Simple plot for illustrating xticks (with default labels)






Set ticks and tick labels

ticks = ax.set_xticks([0, 250, 500, 750, 1000])
labels = ax.set_xticklabels(["one", "two", "three", "four", "five"],
                            rotation=30, fontsize=8)



ax.set_xlabel("Stages")
ax.set_title("My first matplotlib plot")









Figure 9-9. Simple plot for illustrating custom xticks






rotation: Sets tick label rotation (e.g., 30 degrees).
set_xlabel: Names the x-axis.
set_title: Sets the subplot title.





Axes class has a set method:

ax.set(title="My first matplotlib plot", xlabel="Stages")




Legends identify plot elements.
Pass the label argument when adding plot elements:

fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(np.random.randn(1000).cumsum(), color="black", label="one")
ax.plot(np.random.randn(1000).cumsum(), color="black", linestyle="dashed", label="two")
ax.plot(np.random.randn(1000).cumsum(), color="black", linestyle="dotted", label="three")
ax.legend()









Figure 9-10. Simple plot with three lines and legend









ax.legend(): Automatically creates a legend.
loc: Specifies legend location (default is "best").
Exclude elements: Pass no label or label="_nolegend_".





Add custom annotations: text, arrows, shapes.
text, arrow, annotate functions.
ax.text(x, y, "Hello world!", family="monospace", fontsize=10): Draws text at (x, y).





Example: Plotting S&P 500 closing price since 2007 with annotations.

from datetime import datetime

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

data = pd.read_csv("examples/spx.csv", index_col=0, parse_dates=True)
spx = data["SPX"]

spx.plot(ax=ax, color="black")

crisis_data = [
    (datetime(2007, 10, 11), "Peak of bull market"),
    (datetime(2008, 3, 12), "Bear Stearns Fails"),
    (datetime(2008, 9, 15), "Lehman Bankruptcy")
]

for date, label in crisis_data:
    ax.annotate(label, xy=(date, spx.asof(date) + 75),
                xytext=(date, spx.asof(date) + 225),
                arrowprops=dict(facecolor="black", headwidth=4, width=2,
                                headlength=4),
                horizontalalignment="left", verticalalignment="top")

# Zoom in on 2007-2010
ax.set_xlim(["1/1/2007", "1/1/2011"])
ax.set_ylim([600, 1800])

ax.set_title("Important dates in the 2008-2009 financial crisis")









Figure 9-11. Important dates in the 2008‚Äì2009 financial crisis









ax.annotate: Draws labels at specified (x, y) coordinates.
set_xlim, set_ylim: Manually set plot boundaries.
ax.set_title: Adds a main title.





matplotlib has objects called patches representing shapes.
Rectangle, Circle: Found in matplotlib.pyplot.
Full set: matplotlib.patches.
Add to plot using ax.add_patch:

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

rect = plt.Rectangle((0.2, 0.75), 0.4, 0.15, color="black", alpha=0.3)
circ = plt.Circle((0.7, 0.2), 0.15, color="blue", alpha=0.3)
pgon = plt.Polygon([[0.15, 0.15], [0.35, 0.4], [0.2, 0.6]],
                    color="green", alpha=0.5)

ax.add_patch(rect)
ax.add_patch(circ)
ax.add_patch(pgon)









Figure 9-12. Data visualization composed from three different patches









savefig instance method: Saves the active figure.
Example:

fig.savefig("figpath.svg")

File type inferred from extension (e.g., .pdf, .png).
dpi: Controls dots-per-inch resolution.

fig.savefig("figpath.png", dpi=400)










Argument
Description




fname
Filepath or Python file-like object; format inferred from extension


dpi
Resolution in dots per inch


facecolor
Figure background color outside subplots (default: "w" - white)


edgecolor
Color of the figure edge


format
Explicit file format (e.g., "png", "pdf", "svg")









Table 9-2. Some fig.savefig options







matplotlib has configurations for color schemes and defaults.
Customize via global parameters: figure size, subplot spacing, colors, fonts, etc.
rc method: Modifies configuration programmatically.
Example: Set default figure size to 10x10.

plt.rc("figure", figsize=(10, 10))




Current settings: plt.rcParams dictionary.
Restore defaults: plt.rcdefaults().





First rc argument: Component to customize (e.g., "figure", "axes", "xtick").
Followed by keyword arguments for new parameters.
Example:

plt.rc("font", family="monospace", weight="bold", size=8)




Extensive customization: matplotlibrc file in matplotlib/mpl-data.
Place a customized matplotlibrc in your home directory as .matplotlibrc.
Loaded each time you use matplotlib.





seaborn uses matplotlib‚Äôs configuration system internally.
seaborn has built-in plot themes and styles.





Matplotlib can be low-level.
pandas: Built-in methods for visualizing DataFrame and Series objects.
seaborn: High-level statistical graphics library built on matplotlib.
seaborn simplifies creating common visualization types.





Series and DataFrame have a plot attribute.
plot() makes line plots by default:

s = pd.Series(np.random.standard_normal(10).cumsum(), index=np.arange(0, 100, 10))
s.plot()









Figure 9-13. Simple Series plot






Series index: Used for x-axis (disable with use_index=False).
xticks, xlim, yticks, ylim: Adjust axis ticks and limits.











Argument
Description




label
Label for plot legend


ax
matplotlib subplot object to plot on


style
Style string (e.g., "ko--")


alpha
Plot fill opacity (0 to 1)


kind
Plot type: "area", "bar", "barh", "density", "hist", "kde", "line", "pie"


figsize
Size of the figure object


logx
Logarithmic scaling on x-axis


logy
Logarithmic scaling on y-axis


title
Title for the plot


use_index
Use object index for tick labels


rot
Rotation of tick labels (0-360)


xticks
Values for x-axis ticks


yticks
Values for y-axis ticks


xlim
x-axis limits (e.g., [0, 10])


ylim
y-axis limits


grid
Display axis grid (off by default)









Table 9-3. Series.plot method arguments




pandas plotting methods accept an optional ax parameter for a matplotlib subplot object.




df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.standard_normal((10, 4)).cumsum(0),
                  columns=["A", "B", "C", "D"],
                  index=np.arange(0, 100, 10))
plt.style.use('grayscale') #use grayscale style to adapt to black and white publication
df.plot()









Figure 9-14. Simple DataFrame plot






Plots each column as a separate line on the same subplot.
Creates a legend automatically.
df.plot() is equivalent to df.plot.line().











Argument
Description




subplots
Plot each DataFrame column in a separate subplot


layout
2-tuple (rows, columns) for subplot layout


sharex
If subplots=True, share x-axis ticks and limits


sharey
If subplots=True, share y-axis


legend
Add a subplot legend (True by default)


sort_columns
Plot columns in alphabetical order (default: use existing order)









Table 9-4. DataFrame-specific plot arguments




Additional keyword arguments are passed to matplotlib plotting functions.





plot.bar(): Vertical bar plots.
plot.barh(): Horizontal bar plots.
Series/DataFrame index: Used for x (bar) or y (barh) ticks.

fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1)
data = pd.Series(np.random.uniform(size=16), index=list("abcdefghijklmnop"))
data.plot.bar(ax=axes[0], color="black", alpha=0.7)
data.plot.barh(ax=axes[1], color="black", alpha=0.7)









Figure 9-15. Horizonal and vertical bar plot








df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.uniform(size=(6, 4)),
                  index=["one", "two", "three", "four", "five", "six"],
                  columns=pd.Index(["A", "B", "C", "D"], name="Genus"))
df.plot.bar()









Figure 9-16. DataFrame bar plot






Groups values in each row in bars, side by side.
DataFrame column name: Used for legend title.





stacked=True: Creates stacked bar plots.
Values in each row are stacked together.

df.plot.barh(stacked=True, alpha=0.5)









Figure 9-17. DataFrame stacked bar plot









Visualize tipping data: Percentage of data points for each party size, per day.
read_csv: Load data.
crosstab: Cross-tabulation by day and party size.
Calculate the frequency of two columns in the dataframe.

tips = pd.read_csv("examples/tips.csv")
party_counts = pd.crosstab(tips["day"], tips["size"])
party_counts = party_counts.reindex(index=["Thur", "Fri", "Sat", "Sun"])
# Remove 1- and 6-person parties
party_counts = party_counts.loc[:, 2:5]

# Normalize to sum to 1
party_pcts = party_counts.div(party_counts.sum(axis="columns"), axis="index")
party_pcts.plot.bar(stacked=True)









Figure 9-18. Fraction of parties by size within each day









seaborn simplifies plotting with aggregated/summarized data.
Example: Tipping percentage by day.

import seaborn as sns

tips["tip_pct"] = tips["tip"] / (tips["total_bill"] - tips["tip"])
sns.barplot(x="tip_pct", y="day", data=tips, orient="h")









Figure 9-19. Tipping percentage by day with error bars






data: pandas DataFrame.
Other arguments: Column names.
Bars: Average value of tip_pct.
Black lines: 95% confidence interval.





hue option in seaborn.barplot: Split by another categorical value.

sns.barplot(x="tip_pct", y="day", hue="time", data=tips, orient="h")









Figure 9-20. Tipping percentage by day and time









seaborn automatically adjusts plot aesthetics:

Color palette.
Plot background.
Grid line colors.

seaborn.set_style: Switch between plot appearances.

sns.set_style("whitegrid")

For grayscale, set a greyscale color palette:

sns.set_palette("Greys_r")




Histogram: Discretized display of value frequency.
Data points are binned, and the count in each bin is plotted.
plot.hist: Create a histogram.

tips["tip_pct"].plot.hist(bins=50)









Figure 9-21. Histogram of tip percentages









Density plot: Estimate of a continuous probability distribution.
Approximated as a mixture of kernels (e.g., normal distribution).
Also known as kernel density estimate (KDE) plots.
plot.density: Create a density plot.

tips["tip_pct"].plot.density()









Figure 9-22. Density plot of tip percentages











Note



Density plot require SciPy: conda install scipy






seaborn simplifies histograms and density plots.
histplot: Plots both histogram and continuous density estimate.
Example: Bimodal distribution.

comp1 = np.random.standard_normal(200)
comp2 = 10 + 2 * np.random.standard_normal(200)
values = pd.Series(np.concatenate([comp1, comp2]))
sns.histplot(values, bins=100, color="black")









Figure 9-23. Normalized histogram of normal mixture









Examine the relationship between two 1D data series.
Example: Load macrodata, compute log differences.

macro = pd.read_csv("examples/macrodata.csv")
data = macro[["cpi", "m1", "tbilrate", "unemp"]]
trans_data = np.log(data).diff().dropna()




regplot: Makes a scatter plot and fits a linear regression line.

ax = sns.regplot(x="m1", y="unemp", data=trans_data)
ax.title("Changes in log(m1) versus log(unemp)")









Figure 9-24. A seaborn regression/scatter plot









Explore scatter plots among a group of variables.
seaborn.pairplot: Creates a pairs plot.
Supports histograms/density estimates on the diagonal.

sns.pairplot(trans_data, diag_kind="kde", plot_kws={"alpha": 0.2})









Figure 9-25. Pair plot matrix of statsmodels macro data









Pass down configuration options to individual plotting calls.
Check seaborn.pairplot docstring for details.





Visualize data with many categorical variables.
Facet grid: 2D layout, data split across plots based on variable values.
seaborn.catplot: Simplifies faceted plots.

sns.catplot(x="day", y="tip_pct", hue="time", col="smoker",
            kind="bar", data=tips[tips.tip_pct < 1])









Figure 9-26. Tipping percentage by day/time/smoker









Add one row per time value:

sns.catplot(x="day", y="tip_pct", row="time",
            col="smoker", kind="bar", data=tips[tips.tip_pct < 1])









Figure 9-27. Tipping percentage by day split by time/smoker









catplot supports other plot types (e.g., box plots).
Box plots show median, quartiles, and outliers.

sns.catplot(x="tip_pct", y="day", kind="box",
            data=tips[tips.tip_pct < 0.5])









Figure 9-28. Box plot of tipping percentage by day









Create custom facet grid plots.
See seaborn documentation for details.





Many options for creating graphics in Python.
Focus on interactive graphics for the web: Altair, Bokeh, Plotly.
For static graphics: Use matplotlib and libraries built on it (pandas, seaborn).





Fundamentals of Data Visualization by Claus O. Wilke.

Available in print or online: https://clauswilke.com/dataviz






This chapter introduced basic data visualization with pandas, matplotlib, and seaborn.
Effective data visualization is an active research field.
Explore resources to learn more.





matplotlib is a powerful and flexible library for creating static plots in Python.
pandas provides convenient methods for plotting Series and DataFrame objects.
seaborn simplifies creating many common statistical visualizations and integrates well with pandas.
Effective data visualization is crucial for data analysis and communication.

fig = plt.figure()

ax1 = fig.add_subplot(2, 2, 1)

A 2x2 grid of subplots (4 plots total).

text:
Example: Plotting S&P 500 closing price since 2007 with annotations.

from datetime import datetime

fig, ax = plt.subplots()

data = pd.read_csv("examples/spx.csv", index_col=0, parse_dates=True)
spx = data["SPX"]

spx.plot(ax=ax, color="black")

crisis_data = [
    (datetime(2007, 10, 11), "Peak of bull market"),
    (datetime(2008, 3, 12), "Bear Stearns Fails"),
    (datetime(2008, 9, 15), "Lehman Bankruptcy")
]

for date, label in crisis_data:
    ax.annotate(label, xy=(date, spx.asof(date) + 75),
                xytext=(date, spx.asof(date) + 225),
                arrowprops=dict(facecolor="black", headwidth=4, width=2,
                                headlength=4),
                horizontalalignment="left", verticalalignment="top")

# Zoom in on 2007-2010
ax.set_xlim(["1/1/2007", "1/1/2011"])
ax.set_ylim([600, 1800])

ax.set_title("Important dates in the 2008-2009 financial crisis")

## Introduction to pandas üêº

::: {layout-ncol=2}
- **What is pandas?**
    -  A powerful Python library for data manipulation and analysis.
    -  Think of it as Excel, but much more powerful and flexible, all within Python.
    -  Provides data structures like `Series` (1D) and `DataFrame` (2D) to efficiently store and process data.
-   **Why use pandas?**
    -  Simplifies data cleaning, transformation, and analysis.
    -  Integrates well with other Python libraries (NumPy, SciPy, scikit-learn, matplotlib).
    -  Handles heterogeneous data (different data types in different columns).
    - Large and active open source community

![](./figs/pandas-logo.png)
:::

## Key Concepts: Data Structures

- **Series:**
    -  A one-dimensional labeled array.  Like a single column in a spreadsheet.
    -  Can hold data of various types (integers, floats, strings, etc.).
    -  Has an *index*, which labels each element.
    -  Analogy: A list with custom labels (the index) for each item.

- **DataFrame:**
    -  A two-dimensional labeled data structure.  Like a spreadsheet or a SQL table.
    -  Essentially a collection of Series that share the same index.
    -  Each column can have a different data type.
    -  Analogy: A dictionary where each key is a column name and each value is a Series (the column's data).

## Importing pandas and Conventions

- The standard way to import pandas:

```python
import pandas as pd  # 'pd' is the conventional alias
import numpy as np   # NumPy is often used with pandas

section: Series: Your First pandas Data Structure
text:
Series: Your First pandas Data Structure

Creating a simple Series:

obj = pd.Series([4, 7, -5, 3])
obj

0    4
1    7
2   -5
3    3
dtype: int64


Explanation:

The left column is the index (automatically generated here: 0, 1, 2, 3).
The right column contains the values.
dtype: int64 indicates the data type (64-bit integer).

Accessing Series Data
# Get the values as a PandasArray
obj.array

<PandasArray>
[4, 7, -5, 3]
Length: 4, dtype: int64

# Get the index
obj.index

RangeIndex(start=0, stop=4, step=1)


.array provides the underlying data. Usually a NumPy array, but can hold ‚Äúextension array types‚Äù (more advanced).
.index gives you the index object (labels for each value).

Series with Custom Index
obj2 = pd.Series([4, 7, -5, 3], index=['d', 'b', 'a', 'c'])
obj2

d    4
b    7
a   -5
c    3
dtype: int64

obj2.index

Index(['d', 'b', 'a', 'c'], dtype='object')


Now, we have custom labels (strings) instead of default integer indices.
dtype='object' indicates the index type (strings are considered ‚Äúobjects‚Äù in pandas).

Selecting Data in a Series

Use index labels, similar to dictionary keys:

obj2['a']  # Access the value at index 'a'
-5
obj2['d'] = 6 # Modify the value at index 'd'
obj2[['c', 'a', 'd']]  # Select multiple values

c    3
a   -5
d    6
dtype: int64


Key difference from NumPy: You can use your custom labels for selection!

Filtering and Operations

NumPy-like operations work on Series and preserve the index-value links:

obj2[obj2 > 0]  # Boolean indexing (select values > 0)

d    6
b    7
c    3
dtype: int64

obj2 * 2  # Scalar multiplication

d    12
b    14
a   -10
c     6
dtype: int64

import numpy as np
np.exp(obj2)  # Apply a NumPy function (exponential)

d     403.428793
b    1096.633158
a       0.006738
c      20.085537

Integer Indexing Pitfalls

Integer indexing can be tricky because it‚Äôs label-oriented if the index contains integers.

ser = pd.Series(np.arange(3.))
# ser[-1]  # Error: -1 is not a label in the integer index

Use loc (for labels) or iloc (for integer positions) to be explicit and avoid ambiguity.

ser.iloc[-1]

Pitfalls with Chained Indexing

Avoid chained indexing when assigning values.

# Bad:
# data.loc[data.three == 5]['three'] = 6  # Might modify a copy, not the original

Use a single loc or iloc operation instead:

# Good:
data.loc[data.three == 5, 'three'] = 6  # Modifies the original DataFrame

Rule of thumb: Avoid chained indexing in assignments. It can lead to subtle bugs and SettingWithCopyWarning.

pandas simplifies working with objects that have different indexes.

s2 = pd.Series([-2.1, 3.6, -1.5, 4, 3.1], index=['a', 'c', 'e', 'f', 'g'])

Operations between DataFrame and Series

Broadcasting: Operations between a DataFrame and a Series are applied row-wise or column-wise.

frame = pd.DataFrame(np.arange(12.).reshape((4, 3)),
                     columns=list('bde'),
                     index=['Utah', 'Ohio', 'Texas', 'Oregon'])
series = frame.iloc[0]  # Series is the first row of the DataFrame
frame - series  # Subtract the Series from each row (broadcasting)

          b    d    e
Utah    0.0  0.0  0.0
Ohio    3.0  3.0  3.0
Texas   6.0  6.0  6.0
Oregon  9.0  9.0  9.0


Matching is done on the columns by default.
If an index value isn‚Äôt found in both, the result will be reindexed:

series2 = pd.Series(np.arange(3), index=['b', 'e', 'f'])
frame + series2

          b   d     e   f
Utah    0.0 NaN   3.0 NaN
Ohio    3.0 NaN   6.0 NaN
Texas   6.0 NaN   9.0 NaN
Oregon  9.0 NaN  12.0 NaN


To broadcast over columns, use arithmetic methods and specify the axis:

series3 = frame['d']
frame.sub(series3, axis='index')  # Subtract series3 from each column (match on rows)

          b    d    e
Utah   -1.0  0.0  1.0
Ohio   -1.0  0.0  1.0
Texas  -1.0  0.0  1.0
Oregon -1.0  0.0  1.0


Key concept: axis='index' or axis=0 means you want to match on the rows and broadcast across the columns.

Function Application and Mapping

NumPy ufuncs (element-wise array methods) work with pandas objects:

frame = pd.DataFrame(np.random.standard_normal((4, 3)),
                     columns=list('bde'),
                     index=['Utah', 'Ohio', 'Texas', 'Oregon'])
np.abs(frame)  # Apply NumPy's absolute value function element-wise

              b         d         e
Utah   0.204708  0.478943  0.519439
Ohio   0.555730  1.965781  1.393406
Texas  0.092908  0.281746  0.769023
Oregon 1.246435  1.007189  1.296221


apply: Apply a function along an axis (row-wise or column-wise).

def f1(x):
    return x.max() - x.min()

frame.apply(f1)  # Apply f1 to each column (default)

b    1.802165
d    1.684034
e    2.689627
dtype: float64

frame.apply(f1, axis='columns')  # Apply f1 to each row

Utah      0.998382
Ohio      2.521511
Texas     0.676115
Oregon    2.542656
dtype: float64


The function passed to apply can return a scalar or a Series.
Many common array statistics are DataFrame methods (e.g., sum, mean), so apply isn‚Äôt always needed.

def f2(x):
    return pd.Series([x.min(), x.max()], index=['min', 'max'])
frame.apply(f2)

            b         d         e
min -0.555730  0.281746 -1.296221
max  1.246435  1.965781  1.393406


applymap: Apply a function element-wise to a DataFrame.

def my_format(x):
    return f'{x:.2f}'

frame.applymap(my_format)  # Format each value as a string with 2 decimal places

           b      d      e
Utah    -0.20   0.48  -0.52
Ohio    -0.56   1.97   1.39
Texas    0.09   0.28   0.77
Oregon   1.25   1.01  -1.30


map: Apply a function element-wise to a Series.

frame['e'].map(my_format)

Utah      -0.52
Ohio       1.39
Texas      0.77
Oregon    -1.30
Name: e, dtype: object

Sorting and Ranking

sort_index: Sort by row or column labels.

obj = pd.Series(np.arange(4), index=['d', 'a', 'b', 'c'])
obj.sort_index()  # Sort by index labels

a    1
b    2
c    3
d    0
dtype: int64

frame = pd.DataFrame(np.arange(8).reshape((2, 4)),
                     index=['three', 'one'],
                     columns=['d', 'a', 'b', 'c'])
frame.sort_index()  # Sort by row labels

       d  a  b  c
one    4  5  6  7
three  0  1  2  3

frame.sort_index(axis='columns')  # Sort by column labels

       a  b  c  d
three  1  2  3  0
one    5  6  7  4

frame.sort_index(axis='columns', ascending=False) #Descending sort

       d  c  b  a
three  0  3  2  1
one    4  7  6  5


sort_values: Sort by the values in a Series or DataFrame.

obj = pd.Series([4, 7, -3, 2])
obj.sort_values()  # Sort by values

2   -3
3    2
0    4
1    7
dtype: int64

obj = pd.Series([4, np.nan, 7, np.nan, -3, 2])
obj.sort_values() #Missing values are sorted to the end by default.

4   -3.0
5    2.0
0    4.0
2    7.0
1    NaN
3    NaN
dtype: float64

obj.sort_values(na_position="first")

1    NaN
3    NaN
4   -3.0
5    2.0
0    4.0
2    7.0
dtype: float64


For a DataFrame, you can sort by one or more columns:

frame = pd.DataFrame({'b': [4, 7, -3, 2], 'a': [0, 1, 0, 1]})
frame.sort_values('b')  # Sort by column 'b'

   b  a
2 -3  0
3  2  1
0  4  0
1  7  1

frame.sort_values(['a', 'b'])  # Sort by 'a' first, then 'b'

   b  a
2 -3  0
0  4  0
3  2  1
1  7  1


rank: Assign ranks to data (from lowest to highest).

obj = pd.Series([7, -5, 7, 4, 2, 0, 4])
obj.rank()  # Default: average rank for ties

0    6.5
1    1.0
2    6.5
3    4.5
4    3.0
5    2.0
6    4.5
dtype: float64

obj.rank(method='first')  # Rank according to order in data

0    6.0
1    1.0
2    7.0
3    4.0
4    3.0
5    2.0
6    5.0
dtype: float64

obj.rank(ascending=False) #Descending rank

0    1.5
1    7.0
2    1.5
3    3.5
4    5.0
5    6.0
6    3.5
dtype: float64


DataFrame can compute ranks over rows or columns:

frame = pd.DataFrame({'b': [4.3, 7, -3, 2], 'a': [0, 1, 0, 1],
                      'c': [-2, 5, 8, -2.5]})
frame.rank(axis='columns')

     b    a    c
0  3.0  2.0  1.0
1  3.0  1.0  2.0
2  1.0  2.0  3.0
3  3.0  2.0  1.0


Tie-breaking methods: See Table 5-6.

Axis Indexes with Duplicate Labels

pandas allows duplicate index labels (unlike many other data analysis tools).

obj = pd.Series(np.arange(5), index=['a', 'a', 'b', 'b', 'c'])
obj.index.is_unique  # Check if index labels are unique

False


Indexing a label with multiple entries returns a Series:

obj['a']

a    0
a    1
dtype: int64


Indexing a unique label returns a scalar:

obj['c']

4


Important: This can make your code‚Äôs behavior depend on whether labels are unique or not. Be mindful of this when working with data that might have duplicate labels.
The same logic applies to DataFrames:

df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.standard_normal((5, 3)),
                  index=['a', 'a', 'b', 'b', 'c'])
df.loc['b']

          0         1         2
b  1.669025 -0.438570 -0.539741
b  0.476985  3.248944 -1.021228

df.loc['c']

0   -0.577087
1    0.124121
2    0.302614
Name: c, dtype: float64

Summarizing and Computing Descriptive Statistics

pandas objects have built-in methods for common statistical calculations.
These methods automatically handle missing data (unlike NumPy).

df = pd.DataFrame([[1.4, np.nan], [7.1, -4.5],
                   [np.nan, np.nan], [0.75, -1.3]],
                  index=['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'],
                  columns=['one', 'two'])
df.sum()  # Sum of each column

one    9.25
two   -5.80
dtype: float64

df.sum(axis='columns')  # Sum of each row

a    1.40
b    2.60
c    0.00
d   -0.55
dtype: float64


skipna: Controls whether missing values are excluded (default is True).

df.sum(axis='index', skipna=False)

one   NaN
two   NaN
dtype: float64

df.sum(axis='columns', skipna=False)

a     NaN
b    2.60
c     NaN
d   -0.55
dtype: float64


Some methods require at least one non-NA value:

df.mean(axis='columns')

a    1.400
b    1.300
c      NaN
d   -0.275
dtype: float64


idxmax, idxmin: Return the index label where the maximum or minimum value occurs.

df.idxmax()

one    b
two    d
dtype: object


cumsum: Cumulative sum.

df.cumsum()

    one  two
a  1.40  NaN
b  8.50 -4.5
c   NaN  NaN
d  9.25 -5.8


describe: Generate multiple summary statistics in one go.

df.describe()

         one       two
count  3.000000  2.000000
mean   3.083333 -2.900000
std    3.493685  2.262742
min    0.750000 -4.500000
25%    1.075000 -3.700000
50%    1.400000 -2.900000
75%    4.250000 -2.100000
max    7.100000 -1.300000


For non-numeric data, describe provides different summaries:

obj = pd.Series(['a', 'a', 'b', 'c'] * 4)
obj.describe()

count     16
unique     3
top        a
freq       8
dtype: object


List of descriptive statistics methods: See Table 5-8.
Options for reduction methods: See Table 5-7.

Correlation and Covariance
# Assume 'price' and 'volume' DataFrames are already loaded (see book for details)
# In real situations, you could load the data using:
# price = pd.read_pickle("examples/yahoo_price.pkl")
# volume = pd.read_pickle("examples/yahoo_volume.pkl")

# For demonstration, create dummy DataFrames:

price = pd.DataFrame({
    'AAPL': [150, 152, 151, 153],
    'GOOG': [2500, 2520, 2510, 2530],
    'IBM': [90, 91, 90.5, 91.5],
    'MSFT': [300, 305, 303, 306]
}, index=pd.to_datetime(['2023-10-26', '2023-10-27', '2023-10-30', '2023-10-31']))

volume = pd.DataFrame({
    'AAPL': [100000, 105000, 98000, 102000],
    'GOOG': [50000, 52000, 49000, 51000],
    'IBM': [40000, 41000, 39000, 40500],
    'MSFT': [60000, 62000, 59000, 61000]
}, index=pd.to_datetime(['2023-10-26', '2023-10-27', '2023-10-30', '2023-10-31']))


returns = price.pct_change()  # Compute percent changes
returns.tail()


             AAPL      GOOG       IBM      MSFT
2023-10-26 NaN NaN NaN NaN 2023-10-27 0.013333 0.008000 0.011111 0.016667 2023-10-30 -0.006579 -0.003968 -0.005495 -0.006557 2023-10-31 0.013245 0.007968 0.011050 0.009901
:::

- `corr`, `cov`: Compute correlation and covariance.

```python
returns['MSFT'].corr(returns['IBM'])  # Correlation between MSFT and IBM returns
0.8291737285918034
returns['MSFT'].cov(returns['IBM'])  # Covariance
8.688717548738278e-05

Since MSFT is a valid Python variable name, we can also select these columns using more concise syntax:

returns.MSFT.corr(returns.IBM)
0.8291737285918034

DataFrame methods return full correlation/covariance matrices:

returns.corr()

          AAPL      GOOG       IBM      MSFT
AAPL  1.000000  0.854256  0.924038  0.989172
GOOG  0.854256  1.000000  0.719842  0.882348
IBM   0.924038  0.719842  1.000000  0.829174
MSFT  0.989172  0.882348  0.829174  1.000000

returns.cov()

          AAPL          GOOG           IBM          MSFT
AAPL  0.000177  1.567807e-04  1.575587e-04  1.828619e-04
GOOG  0.000157  1.885524e-04  1.282353e-04  1.641686e-04
IBM   0.000158  1.282353e-04  1.754194e-04  1.499066e-04
MSFT  0.000183  1.641686e-04  1.499066e-04  1.968199e-04


corrwith: Compute pairwise correlations between a DataFrame‚Äôs columns/rows and another Series/DataFrame.

returns.corrwith(returns['IBM'])  # Correlation with IBM returns

AAPL    0.924038
GOOG    0.719842
IBM     1.000000
MSFT    0.829174
dtype: float64

returns.corrwith(volume)  # Correlation with volume

AAPL   -0.974948
GOOG   -0.999841
IBM    -0.824252
MSFT   -0.957479
dtype: float64


Unique Values, Value Counts, and Membership
obj = pd.Series(['c', 'a', 'd', 'a', 'a', 'b', 'b', 'c', 'c'])
uniques = obj.unique()  # Get unique values (not necessarily sorted)
uniques

array(['c', 'a', 'd', 'b'], dtype=object)

obj.value_counts()  # Count occurrences of each value (sorted by frequency)

c    3
a    3
b    2
d    1
Name: count, dtype: int64

pd.value_counts(obj.to_numpy(), sort=False)  # Can be used with NumPy arrays too

c    3
a    3
d    1
b    2
Name: count, dtype: int64


isin: Check membership (vectorized set membership).

mask = obj.isin(['b', 'c'])  # Check if each value is in ['b', 'c']
mask

0     True
1    False
2    False
3    False
4    False
5     True
6     True
7     True
8     True
dtype: bool

obj[mask]  # Select values where mask is True

0    c
5    b
6    b
7    c
8    c
dtype: object


Index.get_indexer: Get index locations for an array of values.

to_match = pd.Series(['c', 'a', 'b', 'b', 'c', 'a'])
unique_vals = pd.Series(['c', 'b', 'a'])
indices = pd.Index(unique_vals).get_indexer(to_match)
indices

array([0, 2, 1, 1, 0, 2])


Unique, value counts, and set membership methods: See Table 5-9.



Histograms

You can compute histograms on multiple related columns using apply and pd.value_counts.

data = pd.DataFrame({'Qu1': [1, 3, 4, 3, 4],
                     'Qu2': [2, 3, 1, 2, 3],
                     'Qu3': [1, 5, 2, 4, 4]})
result = data.apply(pd.value_counts).fillna(0) # fillna(0) replace NaN with 0
result

   Qu1  Qu2  Qu3
1  1.0  1.0  1.0
2  0.0  2.0  1.0
3  2.0  2.0  0.0
4  2.0  0.0  2.0
5  0.0  0.0  1.0


The row labels are the distinct values, and the values are the counts.
There is also a DataFrame.value_counts method, but it computes counts considering each row of the DataFrame as a tuple

data = pd.DataFrame({"a": [1, 1, 1, 2, 2], "b": [0, 0, 1, 0, 0]})
data.value_counts()

a  b
1  0    2
2  0    2
1  1    1
Name: count, dtype: int64



Summary







pandas is your essential tool for data analysis in Python.
Series and DataFrames are the core data structures.
Master indexing ([], .loc, .iloc) for selecting and modifying data.
Understand data alignment ‚Äì how pandas handles operations on objects with different indexes.
Use built-in methods for common tasks (arithmetic, statistics, sorting, etc.).
Be aware of integer indexing pitfalls and chained indexing.
Missing data (NaN) is handled gracefully.
Reindexing and dropping are important for reshaping data.

Consider a dataset with missing values. How would you decide whether to drop rows/columns with missing data, fill them with a specific value, or use interpolation? What are the trade-offs?
Practice and experiment with these concepts. The more you use pandas, the more intuitive it will become!

title: Data Aggregation and Group Operations
text:
This chapter focuses on a critical part of data analysis: data aggregation and group operations. We‚Äôll explore how to categorize a dataset and apply functions to each group, a fundamental step in many data workflows.






Note



We will learn how to use pandas‚Äôs versatile groupby interface to slice, dice, and summarize datasets, similar to how SQL works with relational databases, but with greater flexibility.





We‚Äôll cover the following key operations:

Splitting a pandas object into groups using one or more keys.
Calculating group summary statistics (e.g., count, mean, standard deviation).
Applying transformations within groups (e.g., normalization, linear regression).
Computing pivot tables and cross-tabulations.
Performing quantile analysis and other statistical group analyses.
Using transform and apply methods for general group-wise operations.




Grouping and aggregating data allows us to:

Gain insights from large datasets by summarizing information.
Compare different groups within the data.
Prepare data for further analysis or visualization.
Uncover patterns and relationships that might not be apparent in the raw data.

title: Data Aggregation and Group Operations
text:
The Split-Apply-Combine Paradigm üí°
Hadley Wickham coined the term ‚Äúsplit-apply-combine‚Äù to describe group operations. It‚Äôs a powerful way to think about data manipulation. This process involves three steps:

Split: Data is divided into groups based on one or more ‚Äúkeys‚Äù.
Apply: A function is applied to each group independently.
Combine: The results from each group are combined into a final result.

title: Data Aggregation and Group Operations
text:
Grouping Keys üîë
Grouping keys can take many forms:

A list or array of values.
A column name in a DataFrame.
A dictionary or Series mapping values to group names.
A function applied to the axis index or labels.







Note



It‚Äôs important to realize the latter three methods are shortcuts for producing an array of values to be used to split up the object.

title: Data Aggregation and Group Operations
text:
Example: Simple Group Aggregation
Let‚Äôs look at the image provided in the material.
#| echo: false
#| out.width: "80%"
#knitr::include_graphics("images/groupby.png")


Key and Data: The initial table shows a ‚ÄòKey‚Äô column and a ‚ÄòData‚Äô column.
Split: The data is split into three groups (A, B, C) based on the ‚ÄòKey‚Äô column.
Apply: The Sum function is applied to the ‚ÄòData‚Äô column of each group.
Combine: The sums for each group are combined into a new table.

title: Data Aggregation and Group Operations
text:
Grouping by a Single Column
Let‚Äôs calculate the mean of data1 for each group in key1.

grouped = df["data1"].groupby(df["key1"])
grouped.mean()

key1
a   -0.222295
b   -0.611658
Name: data1, dtype: float64



df["data1"]: Selects the data1 column.
.groupby(df["key1"]): Groups the data by the values in key1.
grouped is now a special GroupBy object that stores the group information.
.mean(): Calculates the mean for each group.
Note the automatic exclusion of None values in key1.

title: Data Aggregation and Group Operations
text:
Grouping by Multiple Columns
We can also group by multiple columns, creating a hierarchical index.

# ‰øÆÊîπËÅöÂêàÊñπÂºè
grouped = df.groupby(["key1", "key2"])
grouped.agg({"data1": ["mean", "std"],
             "data2": ["mean", "std"]})

Now, the data is grouped by unique combinations of key1 and key2.

text:
Unstacking
The unstack() method can reshape the result for easier readability.

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
# Create sample data
df = pd.DataFrame({
    "key1": ["a", "a", "b", "b", "a"],
    "key2": [1, 2, 1, 2, 1],
    "data1": np.random.randn(5),
    "data2": np.random.randn(5)
})

# Group by multiple columns and calculate means
means = df.groupby(["key1", "key2"])["data1"].mean()
means

title: Data Aggregation and Group Operations
text:
Optimized Aggregation Methods
Data aggregation transforms arrays into scalar values. pandas provides optimized methods for common aggregations. Here are some of them.


count: Number of non-NA values
sum: Sum of non-NA values
mean: Mean of non-NA values
median: Arithmetic median of non-NA values
std, var: Sample standard deviation and variance
min, max: Minimum and maximum of non-NA values
prod: Product of non-NA values
first, last: First and last non-NA values
any, all: Return True if any (one or more values) or all non-NA values are ‚Äútruthy‚Äù
cummin, cummax: Cumulative minimum and maximum of non-NA values
cumsum: Cumulative sum of non-NA values
cumprod: Cumulative product of non-NA values
nth: Retrieve value that would appear at position n with the data in sorted order
ohlc: Compute four ‚Äúopen-high-low-close‚Äù statistics for time series-like data
quantile: Compute sample quantile
rank: Ordinal ranks of non-NA values, like calling Series.rank
size: Compute group sizes, returning result as a Series

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text: This chapter introduces how to use Python for modeling, bridging the gap between data wrangling with pandas and model building with specialized libraries. We‚Äôll focus on how to interface pandas with modeling libraries like statsmodels and scikit-learn. This is a vital step in the data analysis workflow.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text: This chapter introduces how to use Python for modeling, bridging the gap between data wrangling with pandas and model building with specialized libraries. We‚Äôll focus on how to interface pandas with modeling libraries like statsmodels and scikit-learn. This is a vital step in the data analysis workflow.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Key Concepts
Before we dive into the specifics, let‚Äôs define some crucial terms:


Data Mining: The process of discovering patterns, anomalies, and insights from large datasets. It often involves using various techniques, including machine learning.
Machine Learning (ML): A subset of artificial intelligence (AI) that focuses on enabling systems to learn from data without explicit programming. ML algorithms build models based on sample data, known as ‚Äútraining data,‚Äù to make predictions or decisions.
Statistical Learning: A framework for understanding data using statistical methods. It overlaps significantly with machine learning but often emphasizes inference and interpretability.
Feature Engineering: The process of using domain knowledge to select, transform, and create relevant features (variables) from raw data to improve the performance of machine learning models. It‚Äôs a critical step in building effective models.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
section: Relationships between DM, ML and SL
text:
Relationships between DM, ML and SL
The relationship between Data Mining, Machine Learning, and Statistical Learning can be represented with a Venn Diagram:





graph LR
    A[Data Mining] --> C(Common Ground)
    B[Machine Learning] --> C
    D[Statistical Learning] --> C
    C --> E[Insights & Predictions]






All three disciplines aim to extract insights and make predictions from data. Machine Learning and Statistical Learning often provide the tools and techniques used within the broader context of Data Mining.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Python‚Äôs Role in Data Analysis
Python has become a dominant language for data analysis due to its:

Rich Ecosystem: Libraries like pandas (data manipulation), NumPy (numerical computation), statsmodels (statistical modeling), scikit-learn (machine learning), and Matplotlib/Seaborn (visualization) provide a comprehensive toolkit.
Ease of Use: Python‚Äôs clear syntax and interactive nature (e.g., using Jupyter Notebooks) make it relatively easy to learn and use, even for those without a strong programming background.
Community Support: A large and active community contributes to the development of libraries, provides support, and creates extensive documentation.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Common Workflow
A typical workflow for model development in Python looks like this:





graph LR
    A[Data Loading (pandas)] --> B[Data Cleaning (pandas)]
    B --> C[Feature Engineering (pandas, other tools)]
    C --> D[Model Building (statsmodels, scikit-learn)]
    D --> E[Model Evaluation (statsmodels, scikit-learn)]
    E --> F[Prediction/Inference]







Data Loading: Use pandas to read data from various sources (CSV, Excel, databases, etc.).
Data Cleaning: Handle missing values, correct errors, and transform data into a suitable format using pandas.
Feature Engineering: Create new features or transform existing ones to improve model performance.
Model Building: Use libraries like statsmodels or scikit-learn to train a model on the prepared data.
Model Evaluation: Assess the model‚Äôs performance using appropriate metrics and techniques.
Prediction/Inference: Use the trained model to make predictions on new data or draw inferences about the underlying relationships.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
section: Interfacing Between pandas and Model Code
text:
Interfacing Between pandas and Model Code
The primary interface between pandas and modeling libraries is often NumPy arrays. pandas DataFrames are built on top of NumPy, making this conversion straightforward.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
DataFrame to NumPy Array
You can easily convert a pandas DataFrame to a NumPy array using the .to_numpy() method.

Important: .to_numpy() is preferred over the older .values attribute for clarity and consistency.

Let‚Äôs see an example:

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

data = pd.DataFrame({
    'x0': [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
    'x1': [0.01, -0.01, 0.25, -4.1, 0.],
    'y': [-1.5, 0., 3.6, 1.3, -2.]
})

print(data)
data_array = data.to_numpy()
print("\nNumPy Array:")
print(data_array)

0   1  0.01 -1.5
1   2 -0.01  0.0
2   3  0.25  3.6
3   4 -4.10  1.3
4   5  0.00 -2.0

NumPy Array:
[[ 1.    0.01 -1.5 ]

 [ 4.   -4.1   1.3 ]
 [ 5.    0.   -2.  ]]

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
NumPy Array to DataFrame
Conversely, you can create a DataFrame from a NumPy array:

df2 = pd.DataFrame(data_array, columns=['one', 'two', 'three'])
print(df2)

Notice how we provided column names when creating the DataFrame from the array.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Homogeneous vs.¬†Heterogeneous Data

Homogeneous Data: If your DataFrame contains data of the same type (e.g., all numbers), .to_numpy() will produce a NumPy array with that data type.
Heterogeneous Data: If your DataFrame has mixed data types (e.g., numbers and strings), .to_numpy() will result in an array with a dtype=object. This means the array holds Python objects, which can be less efficient for numerical computations.


df3 = data.copy()
df3['strings'] = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']
print(df3)

print("\nHeterogeneous array:")
print(df3.to_numpy())

Selecting Subsets of Columns

Categorical Data and Dummy Variables
Categorical variables (e.g., ‚Äòmale‚Äô, ‚Äòfemale‚Äô) need to be converted into numerical representations for most machine learning models. One common approach is to create dummy variables (also known as one-hot encoding).

pandas get_dummies()
The pd.get_dummies() function simplifies creating dummy variables:

print("\nDummy Variables:")
print(dummies)

print("\nDataFrame with Dummy Variables:")
print(data_with_dummies)

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Creating Model Descriptions with Patsy
Patsy is a Python library that provides a convenient way to specify statistical models using a formula syntax, similar to R. It‚Äôs particularly useful for linear models. It is installed automatically with statsmodels. conda install statsmodels

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Patsy Formulas
Patsy formulas use a string-based syntax:
y ~ x0 + x1

y represents the dependent variable (response).
x0 and x1 represent independent variables (predictors).
~ separates the left-hand side (response) from the right-hand side (predictors).
+ indicates including terms, not mathematical addition.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
patsy.dmatrices()
The dmatrices() function takes a formula and a dataset (e.g., a DataFrame) and returns design matrices:

import patsy

y, X = patsy.dmatrices('y ~ x0 + x1', data)

print("y (Design Matrix for Response):")
print(y)
print("\nX (Design Matrix for Predictors):")
print(X)

y (Design Matrix for Response):
[[-1.5]
 [ 0. ]
 [ 3.6]
 [ 1.3]
 [-2. ]]

X (Design Matrix for Predictors):
[[ 1.    1.    0.01]
 [ 1.    2.   -0.01]
 [ 1.    3.    0.25]
 [ 1.    4.   -4.1 ]
 [ 1.    5.    0.  ]]



By default, Patsy includes an intercept term (a column of 1s). This represents the baseline value of the response variable when all predictors are zero.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Suppressing the Intercept
To remove the intercept, add + 0 to the formula:

X_no_intercept = patsy.dmatrices('y ~ x0 + x1 + 0', data)[1]  # [1] to get only the X matrix
print(X_no_intercept)

[[ 1.    0.01]
 [ 2.   -0.01]
 [ 3.    0.25]
 [ 4.   -4.1 ]
 [ 5.    0.  ]]

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
section: Using Patsy with NumPy and statsmodels
text:
Using Patsy with NumPy and statsmodels
The design matrices created by Patsy can be used directly with NumPy functions (like np.linalg.lstsq for ordinary least squares regression) or with statsmodels.

import numpy as np
coef, resid, _, _ = np.linalg.lstsq(X, y, rcond=None) # Added rcond=None
print(coef)

# Convert coefficients to a pandas Series with meaningful names:
coef = pd.Series(coef.squeeze(), index=X.design_info.column_names)
print(coef)

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Data Transformations in Patsy Formulas
You can incorporate Python code directly into Patsy formulas for data transformations:

y, X = patsy.dmatrices('y ~ x0 + np.log(np.abs(x1) + 1)', data)
print(X)

[[1.         1.         0.00995033]
 [1.         2.         0.00995033]
 [1.         3.         0.22314355]
 [1.         4.         1.62924054]
 [1.         5.         0.        ]]


Here, we apply a log transformation to x1. Patsy will look for functions like np.log in the enclosing scope.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Built-in Transformations: standardize and center
Patsy provides built-in functions for common transformations:

standardize(x): Scales x to have mean 0 and standard deviation 1.
center(x): Subtracts the mean of x from each value.


y, X = patsy.dmatrices('y ~ standardize(x0) + center(x1)', data)
print(X)

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Stateful Transformations and build_design_matrices
When apply transformations, such as center and standardize, you should use the original dataset when transforming the new dataset. patsy.build_design_matrices function can achieve this.

new_data = pd.DataFrame({
    'x0': [6, 7, 8, 9],
    'x1': [3.1, -0.5, 0, 2.3],
    'y' : [1, 2, 3, 4]
})

new_X = patsy.build_design_matrices([X.design_info], new_data) # Use design_info from original X
print(new_X)

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Introduction to statsmodels
statsmodels is a Python library for statistical modeling, hypothesis testing, and data exploration. It complements scikit-learn by focusing on statistical inference rather than prediction.

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Types of Models in statsmodels
statsmodels includes a wide range of models, including:

Linear Models: Ordinary Least Squares (OLS), Generalized Least Squares (GLS), etc.
Generalized Linear Models (GLMs): For different types of response variables (e.g., binary, count data).
Time Series Analysis: ARIMA models, Vector Autoregression (VAR), etc.
And many more‚Ä¶

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Estimating Linear Models with statsmodels
Let‚Äôs demonstrate how to fit a linear model using statsmodels. We‚Äôll use both the array-based and formula-based APIs.
First, let‚Äôs create sample data:

import statsmodels.api as sm
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

# To make the example reproducible
rng = np.random.default_rng(seed=12345)

def dnorm(mean, variance, size=1):
    if isinstance(size, int):
        size = size,
    return mean + np.sqrt(variance) * rng.standard_normal(*size)
N = 100
X = np.c_[dnorm(0, 0.4, size=N),
          dnorm(0, 0.6, size=N),
          dnorm(0, 0.2, size=N)]
eps = dnorm(0, 0.1, size=N)
beta = [0.1, 0.3, 0.5]
y = np.dot(X, beta) + eps

title: Introduction to Modeling Libraries in Python
text:
Array-Based API

X_model = sm.add_constant(X) # Add an intercept
model = sm.OLS(y, X_model) # Ordinary Least Squares
results = model.fit()
print(results.params) # Estimated parameters
print(results.summary()) # Detailed summary of results
